question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
Consider a random walk that has transition matrix:

\[P=\begin{bmatrix}
1/4  &  1/4  &  1/4\\
3/4  &  3/4  &  1/4\\
0  &  0  &  1/2
\end{bmatrix}\]

Find all eigenvalues of the transition matrix P (no need to calculate
the eigenvectors at this stage).
sols:
The eigenvalues of P satisfy

\[\operatorname{Det}(P - \lambda I) = 0.\] Performing the calculation of
the determinant using the co-factor method gives

\begin{align*}
\operatorname{Det}(P - \lambda I) &= 
\operatorname{Det}\left(\begin{bmatrix}
1/4 - \lambda  &  1/4  &  1/4\\
3/4  &  3/4 - \lambda  &  1/4\\
0  &  0  &  1/2 - \lambda
\end{bmatrix}\right)
\\ &= (-1)^{3+3}(1/2 - \lambda) \left( (1/4 -\lambda)(3/4 - \lambda) - 3/16 \right)
\\ &= (1/2 - \lambda)(\lambda^{2} - \lambda)
\\ &= \lambda(1/2 - \lambda)(\lambda - 1).
\end{align*}

Solving $\operatorname{Det}(P - \lambda I) = 0$ gives the eigenvalues:

\[{\color{blue}\lambda = 0, 1/2,1}.\]

If you want to be clever, you don't have to do any calculation to find
the eigenvalues of \emph{P}.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  \emph{P} is a 3x3 matrix and hence has at most 3 eigenvalues.
\item
  Since \emph{P} is a transition matrix we know that
  $\displaystyle \lambda_1 = 1$ must be an eigenvalue.
\item
  Since the first and second row (or first and second colum) of \emph{P}
  are identical, \emph{P} is singular. Singular matrices always have an
  eigenvalue $\displaystyle \lambda_2 = 0$.
\item
  The only non-zero entry in the third row of \emph{P} is the diagonal
  entry $1/2$. Hence $Pe_3 = (1/2)e_3$ and therefore
  $\displaystyle \lambda_3 = 1/2$ is the last missing eigenvalue.
\end{itemize}

We can double check our answer by verifying that the sum of eigenvalues
equals the sum of diagonal entries:

\[\displaystyle
\lambda_1 + \lambda_2 + \lambda_3 = 3/2 = P_{11} + P_{22} + P_{33}\]
hints:
As it always has, the eigenvalues of a matrix \emph{P} are the zeros of
the characteristic polynomial

\[\operatorname{Det}(P - \lambda I)\]

For this simple matrix however, the eigenvalue beg to be spotted without
any calculation.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  How many eigenvalues does a 3x3 matrix have (at most)?
\item
  \emph{P} is a transition matrix. Which eigenvalue do all transition
  matrices have in common?
\item
  Compare the first and the second row (or first and second column). Is
  \emph{P} singular? What does that imply for the eigenvalues?
\item
  The last row is very simple. What happens if you calculate
  \emph{Pe\textsubscript{3}}?
\end{itemize}

This should already reveal all eigenvalues of \emph{P}. If you miss one
hint, calculate the missing eigenvalue from the fact that the sum of the
diagonal entries of a matrix equals the sum of the eigenvalues.
